content: Cian, thanks for jumping on. We've got four big workstreams to lock down for Dublin — Admissions, Bracelets, Pizza, and Sponsors. Let's walk through each one, assign owners, and agree on the reporting chain. I want zero ambiguity on who does what and in what order.
Agreed. Let's start with the one that's most time-sensitive.
This one gates everything else — we can't order bracelets or food until we know final headcount. Here's how I want it sequenced:
Perfect. So the critical path is: Luke & Ishaan → Tim & Manon → Reuban, Rachel & Faith → Tim finalizes. Nothing downstream moves until 1.4 is done.
This is logistics-heavy but straightforward once we have the number.
So the chain is: Design & UX delivers specs → Aryaman handles procurement → Tim handles receiving. Clear.
Everyone remembers the pizza. Let's make sure we get this right.

So: Outreach collects dietary data → Aryaman and I pick the vendor → Tim places and manages the order. And Actions 3.1 and 3.2 can run in parallel — I can start scouting pizzerias while RSVPs are still coming in.
Exactly right. Parallel tracks where possible.
This one's the most critical in terms of revenue. We're short two sponsors and the clock is ticking.

So: Billy builds the list → Design and Media prep the materials → Billy, Liam and Rachel do outreach → Billy and Aryaman close deals → Board is the safety net. And there's a hard 10-day checkpoint for escalation.
Correct. And I want Reuban kept in the loop on sponsor confirmations too — once we close a sponsor, Marketing needs to know immediately so they can plan co-branded content and social posts.
Noted. I'll make sure that's in the reporting flow.
Let me lay it out simply:
And all reporting flows back through either Tim for ops matters or me for Dublin-specific items, with you getting the executive summary on each milestone.
That's it. Let's get everyone moving. I'll send the kickoff message to department heads today. You brief the Dublin-side contacts.
